channel.title: NYT > Arts > Art & Design

item.title: Frank Gehry: 12 Essential, Stunning Projects
item.description: A singular genius, Gehry redefined architecture with joyful buildings like the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles and the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman
item.media:description: The Guggenheim Museum Bilbao in Spain is a game-changing, fish-shaped art museum on the waterfront.

item.title: Frank Gehry, the Disrupter, Opened Their Imaginations
item.description: Architects, artists, clients and partners assess his life and impact over eight decades.
item.dc:creator: Sam Lubell
item.media:description: Frank Gehry in 1988 in front of his famed Santa Monica, Calif., house, its Dutch Colonial core wrapped with a combination of chain-link fencing, corrugated metal, and off-kilter windows and beams.

item.title: Jennifer Packer: Art at the Cosmic Edges of Longing
item.description: Where does a painter’s grief go? Onto the canvas, in spectral realms.
item.dc:creator: J Wortham

item.title: Arthur Szyk: Spotlight Returns to a Forgotten ‘Soldier in Art’
item.description: An exhibition reckons with the revived legacy of an immigrant artist who created ornate illuminations and scathing caricatures of Nazism and the horrors of the Holocaust.
item.dc:creator: Ralph Blumenthal
item.media:description: A 1942 cartoon by Arthur Szyk from Esquire, captioned “December 7, 1941” for the Pearl Harbor attack, shows a cowboy being stabbed in the back by a caricature of Japan’s prime minister, Hideki Tojo, while Hitler and Mussolini look on.

item.title: Miami Beach’s New Art Installation Frolics With the Fishes
item.description: Our critic explores “Reefline,” an underwater public sculpture park that hopes to be a haven for art and corals. But some question the scientific benefits.
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik

item.title: Austria Forms Panel to Study Its Rights to Famed Florentine Diamond
item.description: The Hapsburg family claims the gem, which it secretly kept hidden for decades.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Florentine Diamond, thought lost or stolen for more than a century, was actually secretly kept in a Canadian bank.

item.title: Inside the Museum-Style Home of Michael Ovitz, an A-List Collector
item.description: He is best known as a former Hollywood power broker, but Ovitz has filled his Beverly Hills home with a collection that shows how serious he is about art.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Ovitz and Tamara Mellon in front of “The Seven Deadly Sins,” by Cecily Brown.

item.title: Nashville Closed a Red Grooms Masterpiece. Now the City Wants It Back.
item.description: Art lovers call for the return of a shuttered carousel they say is the casualty of a boomtown razing its own visual heritage.
item.dc:creator: Walker Mimms
item.media:description: Will it ride again? Red Grooms, a Nashvillian by birth, created the Tennessee Fox Trot Carousel — an ode to cultural life and the colorful characters in his hometown--in 1998. By 2003, it had been dismantled. “We were barely even warned it would close,” Grooms recalled. “Spinning one day, then silent the next.”

item.title: Art Gallery Shows to See in December
item.description: This week in Newly Reviewed, Martha Schwendener covers Meredith James’s anti-architecture monument, Franz Gertsch’s take on Patti Smith, Ragnar Kjartansson’s postcard ode, Analivia Cordeiro’s merging bodies and Guanyu Xu’s hovering photos.
item.dc:creator: Martha Schwendener

item.title: Guy Cogeval, Boundary-Pushing Museum Director, Dies at 70
item.description: His innovative approach drew crowds to the Musée d’Orsay, one of France’s flagship cultural institutions, which he led from 2008 to 2017.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Pam Hogg, Iconoclastic Scottish Designer, Dies at 74
item.description: She was a star of London’s post-punk D.I.Y. fashion, art and performance scene, and dressed a generation of rock stars in her otherworldly handmade clothes.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:description: Pam Hogg in 2010. She was refused to be influenced by market forces or to alter her vision. “I’m giving them what they don’t know they want,” she told the BBC.

item.title: Frank Gehry’s Buildings Sound as Marvelous as They Look
item.description: Gehry, who died on Friday at 96, made an invaluable contribution to classical music by designing spaces with stunning acoustics.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.category: Fisher, Richard B, Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College
item.media:credit: View Pictures/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The swooping interior of Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles.

item.title: Library Agency Reinstates Grants Canceled by Trump Administration
item.description: The Institute of Museum and Library Services restored the funding after a federal court ruled that moves to dismantle the agency were unlawful.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.category: Institute of Museum and Library Services
item.media:description: The Washington headquarters of the Institute of Museum and Library Services, which last year issued nearly $270 million in grants for libraries, museums and archives.

item.title: Frank Gehry, Titan of Architecture, Is Dead at 96
item.description: He designed some of the world’s most recognizable buildings, notably the spectacular Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, his masterpiece.
item.dc:creator: Nicolai Ouroussoff
item.media:description: Frank Gehry en 2003, en una ceremonia de inauguración de la Sala de Conciertos Walt Disney de Los Ángeles, uno de los muchos edificios célebres que diseñó en todo el mundo.

item.title: Judging by the Arts Scene, the Circus Is Back in Town
item.description: Across the culture, we’re seeing a resurgence of clowns, tents and more.
item.dc:creator: Kate Guadagnino

item.title: A SoHo Loft That Reflects an Expansive Idea of Home
item.description: In furnishing his own apartment, Gabriel Hendifar created a place where generations and cultures converge.
item.dc:creator: Nick Haramis

item.title: Mel Leipzig, Painter Called the ‘Chekhov of Trenton,’ Dies at 90
item.description: He put fellow New Jerseyans at the center of his work, and a critic praised the “mysterious emotional tensions” in his pictures of ordinary people.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Es Devlin Builds a ‘Library of Us’ From the Books That Shaped Her
item.description: For Miami Art Week, Devlin has created an open-air installation for Faena Art that invites the public to turn her personal library into a communal one.
item.dc:creator: Nazanin Lankarani
item.media:credit: Daniel Terna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Es Devlin sorted through thousands of books for her installation “Library of Us” at the Kadan Productions warehouse in Secaucus, N.J., in October, marking the titles she wanted displayed spine out with yellow tape.

item.title: The Pérez Art Museum Miami Wants to Be the ‘People’s Museum’
item.description: Franklin Sirmans, head of the Pérez Art Museum Miami, discusses building its collection, the dearth of Black art museum directors and navigating Florida politics.
item.dc:creator: Ted Loos
item.category: Perez, Jorge M, Art Museum of Miami-Dade County
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I do believe that we have proved to be the people’s museum in Miami, in a place that has been much more well known for its private collections,” Sirmans said of PAMM.

item.title: Pace, Di Donna and David Schrader Join Forces to Form New Art Gallery
item.description: Pace, Di Donna and David Schrader of Sotheby’s are collaborating on an Upper East Side space that will focus on secondary market sales.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: via Pace Gallery, Photo by Thomas Loof; George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: The exterior of Pace Gallery, New York (left), and the Di Donna Gallery (right). They will merge into a new location on the Upper East Side, and David Schrader will join the leaders of those galleries in a new venture.

item.title: Two Galleries Form New Art Prize
item.description: The FLAG Art Foundation in New York and Serpentine in London have established a 1 million British pound award for five artists.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.category: Serpentine x FLAG Art Foundation Prize
item.media:description: From left: Patti Harris; Hans Ulrich Obrist; Amanda Fuhrman; Glenn Fuhrman, the founder of the FLAG Art Foundation; Bettina Korek, chief executive of Serpentine; and Michael Bloomberg.

item.title: In Egypt, Museums Built of Sand and Salt
item.description: Plus: an unusual late-autumn fruit, an all-local produce store in Hawai‘i and more recommendations from T Magazine.

item.title: When Luca Guadagnino Brought Brazilian Modernism to Milan
item.description: High above the cloistered, elegant city, the director turned a friend’s apartment into a moody and tropical oasis.
item.dc:creator: Guy Trebay and Simon Watson

item.title: On the Eve of Art Basel Miami Beach, a Case of the Jitters
item.description: Fourteen galleries pulled out of the fair this year, while others chose to stay and embrace the art fray. “It’s a good opportunity to be bold,” says one dealer.
item.dc:creator: Brett Sokol
item.media:credit: Martina Tuaty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inside the Miami Beach Convention Center, home of the annual Art Basel Miami Beach fair, December 2024.

item.title: ‘The Artist’ Blends Degas and Dollars, Murder and Mandy Patinkin
item.description: Created by Aram Rappaport for his streaming service, the Network, the historical drama explores the tensions, sometimes deadly, between art and commerce.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Graeber and Brian Karlsson
item.media:credit: Brian Karlsson for The New York Times

item.title: Norton Art Museum Hosts Old Masters From the Leiden Collection
item.description: A show of 76 paintings from the Leiden Collection is on display at the Norton Museum of Art in South Florida.
item.dc:creator: Joseph B. Treaster
item.category: Norton Museum of Art (West Palm Beach, Fla)

item.title: Untitled Art Fair in Miami Spotlights Hard-to-Define Artists
item.description: The new Artist Spotlight section of the Miami event will include 30 galleries focusing on a single artist, some chosen in part for their lack of commercialism.
item.dc:creator: Ray Mark Rinaldi

item.title: Beyond Art Basel Miami Beach, a Lesson in Cuban American History Awaits
item.description: Visitors to the fair will find a city overflowing with history and art, including contemporary graffiti and posthumous museum retrospectives.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri

item.title: Headed to Art Basel Miami Beach? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Here are some tips on navigating the largest Art Basel fair in the United States, which will bring together 283 galleries from around the world.
item.dc:creator: Paulette Perhach

item.title: Jack Pierson in Miami: An Artist and a City in Transformation
item.description: Visits to the area in the 1980s left a lasting impression on the artist and his work.
item.dc:creator: Hilarie M. Sheets
item.category: Bass Museum of Art (Miami Beach, Fla)
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
